before-robot.title: Site and Robot Selection
content: Explore whether you can run a study in the site with your specific robot

before-robot.title: Physical Robot Setup
content: Ensure safe robot transport to the site
Try out wifi connection/setup in multiple locations
Figure out and test charging/batteries + wiring

before-robot.title: Robot Programming
content: Equip and test the robot for obstacle detection
Test Emergency shut-down procedure
Plan for potential collisions despite obstacle detection
Implement protocols for the robot to maintain a safe distance
Avoid people, pets, and objects
Consider mobility aids, such as wheelchairs or canes

before-robot.title: Site Pre-Testing
content: Run small pre-tests with the robot on-site
Verify you are collecting the right data
A priori information/resources for robot
Acquire or plan to build maps
Create maps if needed using LIDAR
Build necessary dictionaries for semantic information
Ensure code for data storage
Develop or check remote monitoring software

before-robot.title: Site Visit
content: Conduct site visit to explore how the robot will move through the space
Explore how the robot will move in the space
Identify potentially challenging areas for locomotion or sensing
Locate power sources for charging

during-robot.title: Robot Maintenance
content: Check the battery health of the robot
Check if all systems continue to function correctly
Check emergency stop

during-robot.title: Documentation
content: Document any changes to the robot
Document any changes to necessary a priori information/environment and resulting robot procedure

during-robot.title: Resetting Experiment
content: Reset code/conditions/props, record when they were reset
Restart robot monitoring software if needed
Restart robot(s) if needed

during-robot.title: Robot Support
content: Plan robot handler schedule and responsibilities
Determine whether someone needs to stay close to monitor robot
Implement systems to inform maintainers/users when errors occur

during-robot.title: Robot Reassessment
content: Check logs for any unexpected behavior or adverse events
Decide if the robot behavior should change or the study stopped for any safety or research purposes

after-robot.title: Robot Transportation Back Home
content: Arrange for safe return/transportation of the robot
Document the condition of the robot

after-robot.title: Scene Teardown
content: Remove additional cameras/sensors added to the environment
Return all equipment
Transfer and erase data from cameras and other recording devices. Erase from devices after transfer

before-researchers.title: Ethics: Consent and Compensation
content: Assess and address potential ethical risks, especially regarding non-consenting individuals (e.g. children)
Develop a strategy for people to contact research team
Develop a procedure to delete data on request
Consider compensating participants by distributing freebies
Obtain ethics approval to do a study in public

before-researchers.title: Data Protection
content: Confirm compliance with local and national data protection regulations (e.g. GDPR in Europe)
Develop strategies to inform passers-by of their right to request deletion of recorded data
Ensure that the length the data is stored aligns with ethics and local regulations

before-researchers.title: Data Storage
content: Estimate how much data you might collect and select a feasible storage solution
Decide how you will back up your data (cloud, harddisks)
Find ways to label data in a way that will be easy to retrieve and synchronize

before-researchers.title: Preparation of Study Materials
content: Prepare observation protocols
Design interview questions
Design participant questionnaires

before-researchers.title: Study Procedure
content: Formulate a study plan
Plan the length of your deployment to capture diverse interactions in dynamic public settings
Plan experimental conditions to be robust enough to work in public

before-researchers.title: Data Collection Equipment
content: Select equipment suitable for documenting your public deployment
Test your equipment and data collection plan in the site
Practice handling recording equipment in busy, crowded, and distractive settings

before-researchers.title: Pilot Data Collection Methods
content: Test and practice how to collect information from participants in mobile, busy settings (interviews, surveys, observations)
Train interviewers on question delivery in mobile, busy settings
Identify locations where post-interaction interviews/surveys can be conducted

during-researchers.title: Participant Support
content: Prepare for mixed reactions and emotions
Prepare for frequently asked questions

during-researchers.title: Data Protection Strategies
content: Evaluate if signage is sufficient and serving its purpose
Ensure Availability of Study Materials
Print sufficient copies of consent forms and information for large amounts of people in public
Keep materials available at hand in an organized manner

during-researchers.title: Documentation of the Deployment
content: Document adjustments to your study plan
Take photos for paper/archival reasons

during-researchers.title: Verify Data Recording
content: Make sure data is stored continuously and correctly
Ensure data recording (non-robot) is verified (ie external cameras)
Have procedures on when/how to check the data

during-researchers.title: Research Support
content: Re-evaluate if the location/method for interviews is suitable
Execute/use personalized checklist

after-researchers.title: Worker Compensation
content: Pay workers (both study/robot handlers)
Pay interviewees (if applicable)

after-researchers.title: Data Processing
content: Label and organize your data in ways that you can easily retrieve later
Verify that you can map participant IDs to recordings
Anonymize data
Erase instances that you do not have permission to store

after-researchers.title: Data Storage
content: Transfer data into long-term archive to avoid running out of space on cameras/robot
Ensure that the length of time the data is stored aligns with ethics approval and local regulations
Create logs of your obtained data to maintain an overview of what data  you have collected

after-researchers.title: Document Initial Observations
content: Write down notes summarizing interesting observations

after-researchers.title: Returning Equipment
content: Remove all study equipment and signage

before-public.title: Seek Approval for Deployment from Site Authorities
content: Check local laws regarding data collection in public, particularly regarding video and audio recordings
Identify authorities at the deployment site and get their approval

before-public.title: Secure Access to Local Infrastructure
content: Get permission from building/area owners for the deployment and study
Secure access to a reliable internet connection for the robot
Secure access to charging sockets

before-public.title: Plan Accessibility
content: Select colors with color vision deficiency in mind
Ensure volume adjustment/subtitling is available when possible
Make note of accessible routes and plan not to obstruct

before-public.title: Inform the Public about the Deployment
content: Train researchers on how to explain the deployment to passersby
Consider advertising the deployment beforehand in local outlets (newspapers, billboards)
Consider informing about the ongoing deployment by placing visible signs in the area or on the robot
Develop a strategy for passersby to receive results of the study

during-public.title: Maintain Contact with Authorities
content: Present intermediate results iteratively to interested authorities

during-public.title: Risk Management
content: Maintain an ongoing dialogue with staff present at the deployment site (e.g. info desk in the building)
Provide contact information to relevant stakeholders (e.g. building managers, emergency responders)

during-public.title: Secure Accessibility and Safety
content: Keep emergency exists accessible
Ensure that the robot can be shut down if necessary

during-public.title: Inform the Public
content: Have a researcher on site who can answer questions and explain the deployment
Provide written information in visible and accessible locations
Put up an info box where study participants can leave their email address if they want to know about the results
Evaluate if any additional outreach efforts are necessary

after-public.title: Engage with Local Authorities
content: Write thank you notes/emails and seek support of future collaboration with local authorities
Send results if desired

after-public.title: Engage Local Infrastructure Providers
content: Pay any costs (e.g. building use fees)
Inform about the completion of the deployment
Send results if desired

after-public.title: Accessibility
content: Remove any posters or other materials from the deployment site

after-public.title: Inform the Public about the Results
content: Report back to the community (e.g. through news articles, popular science events)
